evidence_span: Hydrogen uptake depended primarily on corrosion weight gains of the individual specimens.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk2
evidence_span: The specimens were autoclaved in a $7 . 6 \mathrm { - } \mathrm { L }$ autoclave of the type used for conformance testing in accordance with ASTM Practice for Aqueous Corrosion Testing of Specimens of Zirconium and Zirconium Alloys (G 2) procedures. The autoclaves were run in a static (non-refreshed) mode. Water was distilled and deionized to $1 { \cdot } \mathbf { M } \Omega { \cdot } \mathbf { c m }$ resistivity.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk2
evidence_span: Specimens were pickled prior to autoclaving in $3 \%$ HF $3 7 \%$ $\mathrm { H N O } _ { 3 }$ -Bal $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { O }$ and rinsed in hot, distilled, deionized water.

evidence_span: In the $4 2 0 \mathrm { { ‰} }$ test the effect of nickel is to decrease the variability in weight gains that occurs due to different processing conditions.

evidence_span: Previous testing [1,3] of the Zircaloys showed nickel to have roughly 8 times greater effect over iron and 20 times the effect of chromium on $5 0 0 \mathrm { ‰}$ weight gains.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: In the $3 6 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ tests, the influence of increasing nickel is to decrease the post-transition rates by about $10 \%$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: Garzarolli et al. [4] showed that Zircaloy-2 post-transition corrosion rates obtained from $3 5 0 \mathrm { { \circ C } }$ autoclave data increased for $\Sigma A _ { i } < 1 0 ^ { - 1 8 }$ h, exhibited a minimum at $\Sigma A _ { i } = 1 0 ^ { - 1 7 }$ h and trended slightly higher for $\Sigma A _ { i } > 1 0 ^ { - 1 6 } \mathrm { ~ h ~ }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: However, both Garzarolli and the current work show specific anomalous behavior where the PTR of 0.35 mdd at $\Sigma A _ { i } = 1 0 ^ { - 1 8 } \mathrm { h }$ is substantially greater than the 0.25 mdd observed at $\Sigma A _ { i } = 1 0 ^ { - 1 9 } \mathrm { ~ h ~ }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: However, both Garzarolli and the current work show specific anomalous behavior where the PTR of 0.35 mdd at $\Sigma A _ { i } = 1 0 ^ { - 1 8 } \mathrm { h }$ is substantially greater than the 0.25 mdd observed at $\Sigma A _ { i } = 1 0 ^ { - 1 9 } \mathrm { ~ h ~ }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk9
evidence_span: When quench rates exceed about $2 \%$ we see no evidence of nodule formation and weight gains are less than $7 5 \mathrm { \ m g } / \mathrm { d } \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk10

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk10
evidence_span: Small improvements in corrosion resistance for the more sensitive materials were obtained from tubing produced with a more radial texture.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk10
evidence_span: Stress relieved tubing was generally less sensitive to nodular corrosion than comparable recrystallized tubing.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk10

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk10
evidence_span: Particle size distributions were independent of the material or processing histories.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk10
evidence_span: Large ingots built up by the consumable electrode melting process have some variation in composition along their length.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk10
evidence_span: Thermal processing also introduces some variation because large pieces or groups of smaller pieces in a furnace load do not all see the same combinations of time and temperature.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_020_chunk10
evidence_span: Cold working can be controlled relatively accurately but. as shown by Schemel [1], small displacements of the tube pilger mandrel can result in very different crystal textures, even though the percent reduction and $Q$ -ratio are constant.
